channel.title: Nature Physics
channel.description: Nature Physics offers news and reviews alongside top-quality research papers in a monthly publication, covering the entire spectrum of physics. Physics addresses the properties and interactions of matter and energy, and plays a key role in the development of a broad range of technologies. To reflect this, Nature Physics covers all areas of pure and applied physics research. The journal focuses on core physics disciplines, but is also open to a broad range of topics whose central theme falls within the bounds of physics.
channel.dc:rights: © 2025 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Quantum light steers photoelectrons
item.content:encoded:
Nature Physics, Published online: 07 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03092-4

When driven by nonclassical light, photoemission from a needle tip reveals signatures of strong-field physics, opening up opportunities to control matter and to engineer the building blocks of quantum technologies.
item.dc:title: Quantum light steers photoelectrons
item.dc:creator: Marcelo Ciappina

item.title: Fractional quantization in insulators from Hall to Chern
item.content:encoded:
Nature Physics, Published online: 07 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03072-8

This Review describes the concepts behind generalized quantum Hall effects that can take place without a magnetic field, and summarizes recent experimental manifestations of these phenomena in twisted two-dimensional materials and few-layer graphene.
item.dc:title: Fractional quantization in insulators from Hall to Chern
item.dc:creator: B. A. Bernevig
L. Fu
L. Ju
A. H. MacDonald
K. F. Mak
J. Shan

item.title: Quantum light drives electrons strongly at metal needle tips
item.content:encoded:
Nature Physics, Published online: 07 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03087-1

The common description of strong-field light–matter interaction neglects the quantum-optical nature of the driving field. Now signatures of strong-field photoemission appear in electron energy spectra when driving with non-classical light.
item.dc:title: Quantum light drives electrons strongly at metal needle tips
item.dc:creator: Jonas Heimerl
Andrei Rasputnyi
Jonathan Pölloth
Stefan Meier
Maria Chekhova
Peter Hommelhoff

item.title: Anisotropic mass enhancement in a two-dimensional heavy-fermion material
item.content:encoded:
Nature Physics, Published online: 06 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03067-5

In a heavy-fermion material, hybridization of conduction electrons and electrons in partially filled core-levels enhances the mass of charge carriers. Now, experiments using a two-dimensional heavy-fermion material show that the hybridization can be extremely anisotropic, with the result that the effective mass of charge carriers is direction-dependent.
item.dc:title: Anisotropic mass enhancement in a two-dimensional heavy-fermion material

item.title: A tale of two domes in twisted trilayer graphene
item.content:encoded:
Nature Physics, Published online: 06 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03081-7

A careful investigation of superconductivity in twisted trilayer graphene reveals a two-dome structure, which may be connected to intricate patterns of symmetry breaking in the underlying metallic state.
item.dc:title: A tale of two domes in twisted trilayer graphene
item.dc:creator: Étienne Lantagne-Hurtubise

item.title: Free electrons as a source of nonclassical light
item.content:encoded:
Nature Physics, Published online: 03 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03082-6

Photon sources used in quantum optics are limited in ways that free electron sources may not be. Now, accelerated electrons have been shown to generate non-classical light — this opens up possibilities for quantum experiments at the nanoscale.
item.dc:title: Free electrons as a source of nonclassical light
item.dc:creator: Sophie Meuret
Hugo Lourenço-Martins

item.title: Observation of the nonlinear chiral thermoelectric Hall effect in tellurium
item.content:encoded:
Nature Physics, Published online: 03 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03073-7

Nonlinear thermoelectric transport arising from inversion-symmetry breaking has been predicted theoretically. Now, the nonlinear chiral thermoelectric Hall effect has been experimentally demonstrated for tellurium at room temperature.
item.dc:title: Observation of the nonlinear chiral thermoelectric Hall effect in tellurium
item.dc:creator: Tetsuya Nomoto
Akiko Kikkawa
Kazuki Nakazawa
Terufumi Yamaguchi
Fumitaka Kagawa
